stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the initial blockout and player flow for the first part of the game's overworld. The main focus was iterating on the design to create intrigue and properly tutorialize mechanics like swimming, culminating in a plan for a scripted introductory cutscene and a coin-based progression gate.

development_findings.summary: The project has reached a major milestone: all 15 main courses are structurally complete. The remaining work involves creating the overworld, side levels, and implementing Biobak's graphical reworks.
development_findings.quote: We basically just finished course 15, which means all the main courses are done. Now, all that's remaining is some side levels, Biobak's reworks, and the overworld.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a custom, faster random number generator that unintentionally uses hardware-level timing, making it non-deterministic. He confirmed on real hardware that this prevents reproducible gameplay, which will make TASing (Tool-Assisted Speedruns) impossible.
development_findings.quote: I made a new random function that is faster... The problem is that it kind of uses like true noise on accident so it may be impossible to test this game.

development_findings.summary: The overworld is designed to be highly interconnected, with areas changing based on player progress and secret paths linking different sections.
development_findings.quote: The overworld is going to be very interconnected. And another thing that's going to happen is there's a secret exit from a different overworld here that you can come out from.

development_findings.summary: To teach the game's unique swimming controls non-intrusively, Kaze plans to add a friendly Cheep Cheep in the first water area that holds up a sign with the control scheme, avoiding a frustrating experience for new players.
development_findings.quote: I think literally what we're gonna do is add a cheap, cheap that holds a sign up and the sign is gonna have the controls on it.

development_findings.summary: The overworld design philosophy is shifting from the SM64 model to one more akin to Banjo-Kazooie, with a large, continuous world divided into 15 distinct but connected areas.

To gate progress into the first level and teach the global coin system, Kaze is leaning towards requiring the player to collect a certain number of coins in the overworld to pay an NPC (like a Pachyderm).
development_findings.quote: Since you have global coins here and we need to teach the player how global coins work. It could be something like you have to find coins in the overworld and then you can pay him off to let you through.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is beta testing another, separate game called 'Direct Mario', described as a GTA-style parody where the player deals drugs and shoots people.
Kaze is intentionally delaying fixing a known visual bug with Mario's hat texture because the underlying character model is scheduled to be reworked, and fixing it now would be wasted effort.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed that the project's budget is in the tens of thousands of dollars, primarily to pay contributors like Biobak for their work. He is considering a donation drive to cover costs.
context_findings.quote: The game as a whole is going to cost me in the tens of thousands, just so you guys know. Maybe I will start a donation drive for that or something, I don't know.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering creating a standalone PC version of the game, which would involve removing Nintendo's copyrighted assets to allow for wider, emulator-free distribution.
context_findings.quote: There's a consideration to strip this off copyright stuff and, like, put it out as a PC game as well. So, like, everyone can just play it without needing an emulator.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the overworld is the most critical component of the game, justifying the extensive time spent on its design to ensure it is intriguing and rewarding for players.
context_findings.quote: I think the overworld is the most important part of the game. So we're putting a lot of care into this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze follows a design rule where if players expect an interaction to be possible based on visual cues, he feels obligated to implement that functionality.
context_findings.quote: If a player is disappointed that a feature isn't present, even though it looks like it could be present, then I have to make the feature present. That's kind of my rule for it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses pride in his focus on performance optimization for the N64, contrasting his work with what he sees as a trend of poorly optimized modern games.
context_findings.quote: In a world full of unoptimized piece-of-shit games, this one game runs so well and easily that it can even run on a fucking Nintendo 64. Isn't that crazy? The last game developer alive that cares about performance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's development philosophy is guided by his personal taste; he chooses not to work on projects or game styles that he doesn't find enjoyable himself.
context_findings.quote: I do not like developing games that I personally wouldn't enjoy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned that his growing popularity on Twitter has made him feel he can no longer post freely, so he has humorously moved his 'shitposting' to LinkedIn.
context_findings.quote: I recently ran into the issue that my twitter account got so popular that i can't really shitpost on twitter anymore whatever's on my mind so i started to shitpost on linkedin instead.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for graphically reworking all the game's levels, a significant contribution for which Kaze is paying him a substantial amount.
biobak.quote: Yes, Biobak is reworking all the levels and I have to pay him a lot for that. I hope I can make that back through donations somehow.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides concept art and drawings to guide level design, as Kaze referred to an image Biobak sent for a level entrance.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife, was mentioned in a personal anecdote about a poster in their living room, offering a small glimpse into their shared life outside of development.

key_stories.title: Designing the First Overworld Area
key_stories.summary: Kaze redesigned the opening moments of the game to be more engaging. After finding the initial layout 'lame,' he iterated through several ideas, including a long dock, before settling on a scripted cutscene to introduce the area's key landmarks and create a sense of wonder without frustrating the player.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the first overworld area felt too open and uninspired, allowing the player to immediately walk into the first two courses without any sense of discovery or intrigue.
key_stories.process: Kaze first identified that the layout was boring. He then experimented with adding visual obstructions like a large dune. He considered a long dock to frame the view of a distant lighthouse but discarded the idea after realizing the high risk of players falling into the water and getting frustrated before learning the swim controls.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to use a brief, scripted introductory cutscene showing Mario's boat arriving. This cutscene will pan around to reveal key landmarks like the lighthouse, creating intrigue and guiding the player without a frustratingly long, walkable dock.
key_stories.key_quote: I kind of see how just being able to enter bunny brushwoods right away is pretty lame. We want the player to find course two and then later find out to course one.

key_stories.title: The Accidental 'True Random' Generator
key_stories.summary: In an effort to optimize the game, Kaze created a new random number function. He discovered his new function was non-deterministic, making Tool-Assisted Speedruns impossible. He confirmed this on real hardware and is now left with a feature that is technically superior but problematic for a segment of the community.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to optimize the game by creating a random number generator (RNG) that was faster than the one in the original Super Mario 64.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote a new random function. He discovered it was unintentionally sourcing randomness from low-level hardware processes like the CPU cycle counter and cache timing. He then tested this behavior on both an emulator and real N64 hardware to confirm that the game's outcomes were different on every boot, even from a save state.
key_stories.outcome: The new RNG is non-deterministic, meaning the game cannot be reliably tested or played back for Tool-Assisted Speedruns (TAS). Kaze is conflicted, as he achieved his optimization goal but at the cost of breaking a key aspect of the metagame for speedrunners and testers.
key_stories.key_quote: It kind of uses like true noise on accident so it may be impossible to test this game... every time I load a safe state it's a different one so it's not deterministic.

key_stories.title: The Origin of 'Releaseo'
key_stories.summary: Kaze shared the origin story of his joke game 'Releaseo.' He created it as a direct response to being overwhelmed by fans demanding a release date for another project, channeling his annoyance by putting their comments directly into the game's dialogue boxes.
key_stories.challenge: While developing a previous hack, 'Lost Impact,' Kaze was incessantly spammed with comments from the community demanding to know the release date.
key_stories.process: Out of pure frustration, Kaze stopped development on his main project and created a joke game called 'Releaseo.' He filled the game with annoying sounds and replaced all 150+ in-game text boxes with the actual comments from users who had been begging him for a release date.
key_stories.outcome: This experience illustrates Kaze's occasionally fraught relationship with community pressure and his tendency to channel frustration into creative, satirical projects. It provides context for how he handles audience expectations.
key_stories.key_quote: I got so annoyed with that I was like okay fuck all of you I'm stopping work on this and I am making a game where everything is toads and it's gonna blow your ears out and I'm gonna calling this releaseo.
